author: By Christopher Barnard
title: A New Set of Tastemakers Finds Inspiration in Shakers
description: Though the faith currently comprises one active community with two congregants, Shakerism’s ideals have found new acolytes in the food, fashion, art and design worlds.
content: In August of 1774, eight intrepid Shakers landed in Manhattan from Manchester, England, in search of a home where they could practice their fledgling religion in peace. Nearly two and half centuries later, their presence has returned to the borough; specifically, to a storybook stretch of Commerce Street in the West Village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Why the Road Is Getting Even Rockier for First-Time Home Buyers
description: Investors and corporations are buying up houses and turning them into rental properties. In Charlotte, N.C., that is adding to the hurdles facing would-be buyers navigating a brutal market.
content: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — At her first meetings with clients, many hoping to buy a first home, Sarah Ortiz Hilton runs through a list of warnings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Missiles hit a residential neighborhood in Odesa, killing at least eight, officials say.
description: The local authorities said at least 18 people were wounded in the strike, the first to hit Odesa since early April.
content: At least eight people were killed when two cruise missiles struck a residential neighborhood on the outskirts of the Black Sea port city of Odesa on Saturday, Ukrainian officials said. Given the extent of the damage, officials said the number of victims was certain to climb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Peyser
title: Searching for the ‘Vibe Shift’ at Coachella
description: Unchecked optimism, for better or worse.
content: INDIO, Calif. — A sandstorm whipped dirt and dust into eyes, mouths and all over the bodies of thousands of people. The sky was hazy. Powerful winds had the palm trees flailing all over the place, and the heat reached nearly 90 degrees at times. But not even unfavorable weather conditions could harsh the vibe of this year’s attendees at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson
title: As Western Arms Pour Into Ukraine, Zelensky Promises Victory
description: “The day when they will be forced to leave Ukraine is approaching,” the Ukrainian president said of the Russians, in a sharp change of tone.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky, bolstered by an influx of heavy weapons from Western nations, expressed increasing confidence on Saturday that Ukraine was prepared to defeat Russian forces in what is expected to be a long and brutal battle for control of the eastern industrial heartland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: A Boston Consulting Firm Became a Power Broker, and Then a Pariah, in South Africa
description: A new judicial inquiry found that corruption at South Africa’s tax agency was because of “collusion” between Bain & Company and South Africa’s former president.
content: JOHANNESBURG — As a tax fraud investigator with the South African Revenue Service for 18 years, Ronel van Wyk led a squad that tracked down smugglers and other criminals, with a 90 percent conviction rate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Thompson
title: It’s Not Just High Oil Prices. It’s a Full-Blown Energy Crisis.
description: And it will get worse before it gets better.
content: Americans are worrying about their gas prices. Germans are turning down their heating. Peru has seen violent protests — and a violent crackdown on them — over rising fuel costs. Nigeria’s national energy grid recently collapsed. And that’s just this spring. Focused on the future, the United Nations Intergovernmental Planet on Climate Change warned in a report on April 4 that too much investment is going into fossil fuels and too little into the energy transition that could prevent a devastating increase in global temperatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Warsaw’s Welcome Mat Risks Fraying Under Strain of a New Refugee Surge
description: Warsaw gladly and proudly accepted 300,000 Ukrainians fleeing the war. But as the Polish capital braces for a new wave of refugees, its mayor warns that the city is “at capacity.”
content: WARSAW — Warsaw’s biggest pediatric hospital has put patients from Ukraine on its waiting list for liver transplants, sometimes ahead of Polish children. Schools in Poland’s capital have had to search for extra teachers to keep up with the influx of new pupils. Public transport has risked buckling under the strain of so many new residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: For Trump’s G.O.P., Crossing Lines Has Few Consequences
description: A dizzying week featured Kevin McCarthy, the House Republican leader, caught lying and another lawmaker, Marjorie Taylor Greene, grilled under oath about her role in the Jan. 6 attack.
content: WASHINGTON — There was a time in the nation’s capital when lines mattered, and when they were crossed, the consequences were swift and severe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Feeding my desperate need to make words, one point at a time.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: Meadows Was Warned Jan. 6 Could Turn Violent, House Panel Says
description: The committee investigating the attack also said in a filing that the former White House chief of staff proceeded with a plan for “alternate electors” despite being told it wasn’t legally sound.
content: WASHINGTON — Mark Meadows, the final chief of staff for President Donald J. Trump, was told that plans to try to overturn the 2020 election using so-called alternate electors were not “legally sound” and that the events of Jan. 6 could turn violent, but he pushed forward with a rally anyway, the House committee investigating the Capitol attack alleged in a Friday night court filing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hikari Hida
title: Discreetly, the Young in Japan Chip Away at a Taboo on Tattoos
description: Exposed to body art on social media, more young Japanese are getting tattoos, even if that means hiding them at work.
content: TOKYO — Ayaka Kizu, a web designer in Tokyo, stood by her office desk one recent day, peeling Band-Aids off an apple-size portion of her right arm. A meeting with clients had ended, so she was now free to reveal what lay underneath: a tattoo of a multicolored unicorn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Hermann Nitsch, 83, Dies; Sought Artistic Transcendence in Blood and Guts
description: He was a founding father of the Viennese Actionists, a group of radical artists who used their bodies and other elements to upend art-making at the dawn of the 1960s.
content: Hermann Nitsch, the notorious Austrian performance artist whose elaborate and grisly “actions,” as they were called, often involved slaughtered and disemboweled animals, blood, feces and viscera and evoked Christian and pagan rituals, died on Monday in Mistelbach, a town near his home in Lower Austria. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawna Richer
title: Canada’s Stanley Cup Hopes Rest on Leafs, Flames, Oilers
description: The N.H.L. playoffs are a beloved routine of Canadian springtime that can make fans as crazy as the season’s mercurial weather.
content: It is a rule that spring comes to Canada erratically, a few mild days followed by a foot of snow followed by rain followed by a day so hot you would swear it was summer, usually followed by sleet and more snow. On the day I was born in April my mother needed a heavy winter coat on the way to the hospital, and by the time I had arrived in the afternoon it was hot enough to go to the beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Exxon Bans Outside Flags, Like the Pride Banner, From Company Flagpoles
description: Workers can display the banner on other areas of the company’s properties, including on lawns. The company is allowing a flag representing an L.G.B.T. employee group.
content: Exxon Mobil will no longer allow banners of outside organizations on its flagpoles, angering some employees who in the past had flown a rainbow pride flag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Alice Walker Has ‘No Regrets’
description: Walker has grappled with some of the thorniest issues of 20th-century America. She’s also taken troubling stances. She has now opened up and shared her diaries, giving readers a window into her life.
content: Alice Walker is one of the most renowned — and complex — public figures of her generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Leigh Brown
title: He Ran Marathons in Prison. Boston’s Was Easier.
description: Markelle Taylor started running as an antidote to despair. This week he ran the Boston Marathon as a free man, with a time of 2:52:00.
content: BOSTON — Out of all the runners in the first wave of the Boston Marathon on Monday, there was one lean, muscular marathoner with skinny ankles from Northern California for whom all the nervous energy had profound significance. Markelle Taylor, a former lifer at San Quentin State Prison, was running free for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf, Marc Santora and Emma Bubola
title: Ukrainians lean on Easter traditions in the shadow of a devastating war.
description: In Lviv, residents had laid bouquets of flowers at the feet of a statue of the Virgin Mary, next to piles of white sandbags protecting the statue from bombings.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — On the eve of the most important Christian religious festival of the year, Ukrainians clung to centuries-old Easter traditions in the shadow of a war that has brought devastation and sorrow to much of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why Biden Saying ‘Genocide’ Doesn’t Matter
description: It will neither rattle Putin nor change our obligations in the war.
content: Just over a week ago, Joe Biden acted like Joe Biden and called the Russian campaign in Ukraine a “genocide” — leaping ahead of our major allies, our State Department and the available facts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Protesters Amass at White House, Demanding Action on Climate
description: In Washington, D.C., as well as Phoenix, Atlanta and scores of other cities across the country, demonstrators called on the government to enact bold climate action.
content: WASHINGTON — Environmental activists, distraught by the government’s slow pace of action on climate change, amassed in front of the White House Saturday afternoon, calling on President Biden and Congress to swiftly pass a climate bill that has been stalled in the Senate since December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frederick Kaufman
title: How Covid Breaks All the Rules of Human Narrative
description: We have neither a shared language nor a shared understanding of what we’ve just been through.
content: In popular culture, a successful plot is a recognizable plot — the hero’s epic journey, the marriage’s inevitable consummation, the dashing warrior who slays the monster. Some narratologists argue that there are no more than a handful of basic plots — story lines that are recycled again and again, such as “the quest,” “rebirth” and “rags to riches.” Hollywood producers tend to agree, as illustrated by an old industry joke my father, a screenwriter, once told me about the head of production who demands a movie plot that is exactly the same as the last one — except different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Does the Curriculum Look Like in Your School?
description: We want to hear from you.
content: Florida recently rejected 42 of 132 math textbooks for use in public schools because it said they incorporated elements of social-emotional learning and critical race theory. The state did not specifically share what lessons were considered problematic, but The New York Times has reviewed 21 of the rejected books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A ‘Catalyst’ From the Start, Miguel Cabrera Reaches 3,000 Hits
description: Cabrera’s first manager recalls his star pupil always being in the middle of things. On Saturday, Cabrera collected hits 3,000-3,002 of his 20-year career.
content: The very best players make a manager want to change the rules. Specifically, one rule: that pesky requirement for a lineup, which mandates that each hitter take his turn. When Miguel Cabrera is on your team, the waiting is the hardest part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: The End of the All-Male, All-White Cockpit
description: Airlines are struggling to find enough pilots and to diversify a profession that has been very resistant to change.
content: It’s been a half-century since airlines started hiring women and people of color to fly passenger planes, allowing a handful of pioneering pilots into the flight deck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: In Le Pen Territory, as France Votes, Anger at a Distant President
description: Whatever happens in the runoff election on Sunday, France has changed, and the winner may face a turbulent season.
content: ST. RÉMY-SUR-AVRE, France — Eternal France, its villages gathered around church spires, its fields etched in a bright patchwork of green and rapeseed yellow, unfolds as if to offer reassurance in troubled times that some things do not change. But the presidential election on Sunday, an earthquake whatever its outcome, suggests otherwise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove and Eduardo Medina
title: Charges Dropped Against Tennessee Woman Who Was Jailed Over Voter Fraud
description: Pamela Moses, who was sentenced in January to six years in a case that outraged voting rights supporters, will not face a new trial, a district attorney said.
content: A Tennessee prosecutor dropped all criminal charges on Friday against Pamela Moses, a Memphis woman with a previous felony conviction who was sentenced to six years and one day in prison in January after she tried to restore her right to vote in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Banning Russian Tennis Players Won’t Stop the War. So Why Is Wimbledon Doing It?
description: Sometimes the do-something impulse is too strong.
content: On Wednesday, the All England Lawn Tennis Club (better known as the venue for The Championships at Wimbledon) joined with the British Lawn Tennis Association in banning all Russian and Belarusian players from competing at its event — at least, according to the L.T.A.’s statement, “whilst the current situation continues in accordance with the UK Government guidance in place.” While acknowledging that “individual Russian and Belarusian players may not agree with the actions of their Governments and this is a situation beyond their control,” the statement also said “The continuing participation of Russian and Belarusian nationals at events risks providing a boost to these regimes when there is an unprecedented international effort to isolate them and sanction their actions.” It’s the first time Wimbledon has banned players from specific countries since the end of World War II, when athletes from Germany and Japan were barred from competing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: The Former Chancellor Who Became Putin’s Man in Germany
description: Gerhard Schröder, who is paid almost $1 million a year by Russian-controlled energy companies, has become a pariah. But he is also a symbol of Germany’s Russia policy.
content: HANOVER, Germany — On the evening of Dec. 9, 2005, 17 days after Gerhard Schröder left office as chancellor of Germany, he got a call on his cellphone. It was his friend President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins and Stephanie Nolen
title: The Drive to Vaccinate the World Against Covid Is Losing Steam
description: Rates are stalling in most low-income countries well short of the W.H.O.’s goal to immunize 70 percent of people in every nation. Some public health experts believe the momentum is gone forever.
content: In the middle of last year, the World Health Organization began promoting an ambitious goal, one it said was essential for ending the pandemic: fully vaccinate 70 percent of the population in every country against Covid-19 by June 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Magazine Racket
description: Make some noise for Sam Ezersky’s scheming Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This grid solved for me like a giant Saturday puzzle that happened to have a theme. A high difficulty level is to be expected from Sam Ezersky, who has been constructing mainly for Friday and the weekend for a few years now (when he gets a break from the Spelling Bee hive, of course, and his day job as the digital puzzles editor). This is Mr. Ezersky’s 38th crossword for The Times, and it corresponds to the day that he will be running the Brooklyn Half Marathon, in case you want to cheer him on. Undaunted, Sam is not. He said, “Hoping solvers won’t be struggling on Sunday morning as much as me!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Coach’s Prayers Prompt Supreme Court Test of Religious Freedom
description: Joseph Kennedy, a football coach at a public high school in Washington State, lost his job after praying on the 50-yard line after games.
content: BREMERTON, Wash. — Joseph Kennedy, who used to be an assistant coach for a high school football team near Seattle, pointed to the spot on the 50-yard line where he would take a knee and offer prayers after games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin and Emily Erdos
title: Mask Ruling Underscores Deep Split in Attitudes
description: Many readers of The Times said a judge’s decision to strike down the mask mandate on public transportation was “political” and “outrageous.” Others called it a relief.
content: Wearing masks during the pandemic has long been a divisive issue in the United States. And now that a federal judge has tossed out the mask mandate for planes and public transportation, rules in some places have been thrown into chaos. Many were lifted, and a few reimposed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Melissa Clark’s Saturday Recipe
description: A good weekend is one in which you break with the routines of the week.
content: Consider the weekend, two entire days uncharted and unblemished, if you’re lucky, blanks to fill in however you wish. That is the view of the weekend from afar — from Thursday, say — when the demands of work or school chafe and you fantasize about how you’ll fill those unscheduled hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: On Jan. 7, Could Republicans Have Made a Break From Trump?
description: There was a slim window to force them to act. It passed.
content: On Thursday, my newsroom colleagues Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin reported on the Republican leaders who in private condemned President Donald Trump for the attack on the Capitol and hoped to hold him accountable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: These Parties Start With a Blank Canvas (and a Little Cannabis)
description: New York State is mapping out plans to license venues for on-site recreational marijuana use, but some places have already figured out how to get the ball rolling.
content: This story is part of an occasional series exploring nightlife in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: How to Make School Board Culture Wars Even Worse
description: Tennessee has a plan for that.
content: FRANKLIN, Tenn. — “What happens when a child sounds out the word ‘lesbian’ and turns to their teacher and asks, ‘What is a lesbian?’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Exploring the Health Effects of Ageism
description: Through more than three decades of research, the Yale psychologist Becca Levy has demonstrated that age discrimination can take years off one’s life.
content: Each fall, Becca Levy asks the students in her health and aging class at the Yale School of Public Health to picture an old person and share the first five words that come to mind. Don’t think too much, she tells them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Rattled by Ukraine War, Moldova Strives to Dodge Russia’s Long Shadow
description: Moldova’s destiny has been intertwined uncomfortably with Russia’s for years, and the Ukraine invasion has accelerated its efforts to break free from Moscow.
content: CHISINAU, Moldova — Before war erupted next door, Moldovans had big plans for their country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Homeroom on the Job
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 23, 2022.
content: “It’s like hiring a soccer player and saying, ‘I don’t care how many goals you score, I only care how many hours you train.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: How Remote Work Helped Tech Companies Outside Silicon Valley Grow
description: Some companies that hired remote workers during the pandemic say going back to the office isn’t an option.
content: More than two years after the pandemic sent workers packing and hunkering down in their home offices, many companies are now doing everything they can to lure employees back in office buildings — at least for a few days a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: My Neighbor’s Hoarding Is Befouling the Building. What Can We Do?
description: Residents are entitled to safe and habitable living conditions, despite a neighbor’s mental health struggles. You may have to act forcefully.
content: Q: A shareholder in our small, self-managed co-op is in his 80s and has dementia. His unit is in need of maintenance, cleaning and decluttering because of hoarding. The building now has a roach infestation. At significant cost to the co-op, we fumigated the building; we also packed up and removed items in his unit, fumigated them and returned them to him. He has never unpacked the boxes, and new clutter has accumulated around them. The roach problem continues. We’ve contacted his adult children, hoping they could help, but they have not. What are our options?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: Filing Provides New Details on Trump White House Planning for Jan. 6
description: Testimony disclosed by the House committee investigating the attack showed that Mark Meadows and Freedom Caucus members discussed directing marchers to the Capitol as Congress certified the election results.
content: WASHINGTON — Before the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, Trump White House officials and members of the right-wing House Freedom Caucus strategized about a plan to direct thousands of angry marchers to the building, according to newly released testimony obtained by the House committee investigating the riot and former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Chen, Stefanos Chen and Jingyu Lin
title: Chinatown’s Civic Groups Have Held Developers at Bay. Can They Survive?
description: The groups have held back gentrification in an area surrounded by development. The future of one of Manhattan’s few working-class neighborhoods is at stake.
content: For decades, the Lee Family Association, one of the oldest civic groups in Manhattan’s Chinatown, has helped countless Chinese immigrants, working from its six-story building on Mott Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Man Charged With Threatening Merriam-Webster Over Gender Definitions
description: The man, Jeremy David Hanson, 34, threatened in October to shoot and bomb the company’s offices because of its definitions of “girl,” “boy,” “trans woman” and other words, federal authorities said.
content: A California man was arrested this week on charges that he sent messages to Merriam-Webster in which he threatened to shoot and bomb its offices because he didn’t like the company’s dictionary definitions relating to gender identity, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri
title: Sonia Boyce Wins Top Prize at Venice Biennale
description: Boyce, the first Black woman to represent Britain at the Venice event, won the Golden Lion for her sound installation of five Black British female musicians singing a cappella.
content: VENICE — The artist Sonia Boyce won Britain the top prize at the Venice Art Biennale, the world’s longest-running and most high-profile international exhibition of contemporary art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Molars, Reticence and Eco-Warriors
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: Hello, readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Long-Lost ‘Wizard of Oz’ Dress Goes on Display Before Auction
description: The dress worn by Judy Garland was given to a priest at the Catholic University of America in 1973, but had been missing for decades when it was found in a shoe box last year.
content: In an indelible scene from “The Wizard of Oz,” the vivid green Wicked Witch held a frightened Dorothy captive by threatening harm to her dog Toto if she did not give up her ruby-red slippers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
title: 26 Missing From Japanese Tour Boat After Distress Call off Hokkaido
description: The sightseeing vessel was on a three-hour round trip tour to the tip of Cape Shiretoko. The Japan Coast Guard had dispatched rescue boats and aircraft to the area near the Kashuni Falls.
content: TOKYO — All 26 people aboard a sightseeing boat were reported missing off the coast of Hokkaido, Japan’s northernmost island, on Saturday after the boat made a distress call to the Japan Coast Guard early in the afternoon saying it was sinking.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Liana Finck Reimagines the Story of Genesis
description: Finck talks about “Let There Be Light,” and Jonathan Van Ness discusses “Love That Story.”
content: The cartoonist Liana Finck’s new book, “Let There Be Light,” recasts the story of Genesis with a female God who is a neurotic artist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: All Made Up, Perhaps
description: Dive into Matthew Stock’s clean and clever Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I missed the cool geometric element of this puzzle entirely, until I read Matthew Stock’s notes and mentally swiveled the grid 45 degrees to the right. That showed me that the puzzle divides neatly in half on the diagonal, and my problem entries mainly inhabited the left (or southwest) side. This is Mr. Stock’s first solo Saturday grid; he collaborated with Sid Sivakumar last May on another distinctive-looking Saturday themeless.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Shifting Norms on Tattoos in Japan
description: Norms surrounding tattoos in Japan are slowly but steadily changing, especially among the younger generation.
content: Norms surrounding tattoos in Japan are slowly but steadily changing, especially among the younger generation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Jan. 6 Committee’s Filing in Its Lawsuit With Mark Meadows
description: The committee alleged that Mark Meadows, the final chief of staff for President Donald J. Trump, was told that an effort to try to overturn the 2020 election using so-called alternate electors were not “legally sound” and that Jan. 6 could turn violent, but he pushed forward with plans to hold a rally in Washington anyway.
content: The committee alleged that Mark Meadows, the final chief of staff for President Donald J. Trump, was told that an effort to try to overturn the 2020 election using so-called alternate electors were not “legally sound” and that Jan. 6 could turn violent, but he pushed forward with plans to hold a rally in Washington anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Fremson and Audra D. S. Burch
title: Olmsted’s Enduring Gift
description: The man behind many of the nation’s beloved public spaces, Frederick Law Olmsted, was born 200 years ago on April 26. His creations are more essential to modern American life than ever.
content: The man behind many of the nation’s beloved public spaces, Frederick Law Olmsted, was born 200 years ago on April 26. His creations are more essential to modern American life than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Chat With Conservative Men
description: Some liberals were surprised by how much they agreed with members of the focus group, while other readers were more critical.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 23, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 23, 2022.
content: An article on Thursday about Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany and the debate over sending heavy weapons to Ukraine misstated the name of a German infantry-fighting vehicle. It is the Marder, not the Mardar.
source.name: The New York Times
